introduction.p:
Clausius's theorem states that the following inequality holds for all cyclic processes.
\oint \frac{dQ}{T}\le 0.

Consider an arbitrary system X that undergoes a cyclic process. In each cycle the system receives or gives up heat to a set of thermal baths at temperatures T_1, T_2, \cdots, T_n. A Carnot engine is an example of this kind of system with only two heat baths where every process is reversible. Here we assume that some or all of the processes of X may be irreversible. Let Q_1, Q_2, \cdots, Q_n be the heat exchanged by X and the thermal baths at T_1 , T_2 , \cdots , T_n respectively with the sign notation that Q_i will be positive if heat flows in X and negative if heat flows out of X to a thermal bath. We will prove that
\sum_{i=1}^n \frac{Q_i}{T_i} \le 0.

Once we have proved this, we can immediately obtain the theorem by considering the case where the system exchanges heat with infinitely many baths. In that case the sum in Eq. will turn into integral in Eq. .
To proceed with the proof, we introduce reversible engines such as Carnot engines C_1, C_2, \cdots, C_n between the baths and a common heat bath at temperature T_0 as shown in .

figure.caption: System undergoing a cyclic process interacting with heat baths T_1, T_2, \cdots, T_n. Carnot cycles operate between these heat baths and a common heat bath T_0.

introduction.p:
We will pick Carnot engines such that the i^\text{th} Carnot cycle replenishes heat exchanged by the i^\text{th} heat bath and X. Each Carnot cycle has the following relation between its temperatures of operation and the corresponding heat exchanged.
\amp C_1:\ \ \ \ Q_{01} = \frac{Q_1}{T_1}T_0, \amp C_2:\ \ \ \ Q_{02} = \frac{Q_2}{T_2}T_0, \amp \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \vdots \ \ \ \ \ \ \amp C_n:\ \ \ \ Q_{0n} = \frac{Q_n}{T_n}T_0.

Now if we look at one cycle of the complex system consisting of X and the carnot cycles C_1, C_2, \cdots, C_n, we find that it absorbs a net heat
Q_0 = Q_{01} + Q_{02} + \cdots + Q_{0n},
and does the same amount of work. Therefore the complex system [X, C_1 , C_2 , \cdots , C_n] will violate the Kelvin-Planck statement of the second law of thermodynamics if heat Q_0 was positive. That would mean a net intake of heat to the system in one cycle all of which converted to work without any other change, which, according to the second law, cannot happen. Therefore, second law forbids Q_0 from being positive. Hence,
Q_0 = \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{Q_i}{T_i} T_0 \le 0.
Since T_0>0 , we obtain the desired result.
\sum_{i=1}^n \frac{Q_i}{T_i} \le 0.
Considering the case where system X exchanges infinitesimal amount of heat with infinitely many baths turns the sum into integral over the cycle of the system: \oint \dfrac{dQ}{T}\le 0.
